questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following marked structures is the space of Gillette?
questions.explanation:
Option 1 is Gillette’s space. Retropharyngeal space is divided into two lateral compartments (spaces of Gillette) by a median 
fibrous raphe. Option 2 - Danger space - between alar fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly. Option 3 - Prevertebral space. Option 4 - Anterior cervical space. 487 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: An ENT surgeon is performing an incision and drainage for a retropharyngeal abscess due to 
suppurative lymphadenitis. Which among the following groups of lymph nodes is most likely 
to be involved?
questions.explanation:
Rouvier Nodes or retropharyngeal lymph nodes suppurate to form retropharyngeal abscess. Each lateral compartment of retropharyngeal space contains lymph nodes that usually disappear 
at 3-4 years of age. Suppuration of these lymph nodes is the most common cause of 
retropharyngeal space abscess in children. Option B - Delphian nodes are the pre-laryngeal lymph nodes. Option C - Virchow's node is the left supraclavicular lymph node. Option D - Cloquet’s nodes are the deep inguinal lymph nodes.

questions.question:
Question 3: 480 
Sold by @itachibot A concerned mother brought her toddler to the ER with complaints of noisy breathing and 
the child refusing to feed. On examination, the child has adenoid facies and there is a bulge in 
the posterior pharyngeal wall lateral to the midline. Which of the following is a false 
statement regarding the disease described above?

options.a: Suppuration of nodes of Rouvier can cause the above condition
options.b: Caries of the cervical spine is the most common cause
options.c: In adults similar condition may result from penetrating injury of the cervical esophagus
options.d: Torticollis is one of the symptoms.

questions.explanation:
The above clinical condition is suggestive of acute retropharyngeal abscess whereas caries of the 
cervical spine results in a chronic retropharyngeal abscess. Acute retropharyngeal abscess is commonly seen in children below 3 years. It is the result of 
suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to infection in the adenoids, nasopharynx, 
posterior nasal sinuses, or nasal cavity. In adults, it may result from penetrating injury of the posterior pharyngeal wall or cervical 
esophagus. Clinical features of a retropharyngeal abscess include • Dysphagia and difficulty in breathing - as the abscess obstructs the air and food passages. • Stridor and croupy cough • Torticollis - the neck becomes stiff and the head is kept extended. • A bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall, usually seen on one side of the midline. Chronic retropharyngeal abscess is the result of • Caries of the cervical spine • Tuberculous infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to tuberculosis of deep cervical 
nodes.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 42-year-old HIV positive man presents with an acute onset high-grade fever with chills and 
shortness of breath. On evaluation, he's diagnosed to have a necrotising mediastinitis 
secondary to rupture of a retropharyngeal abscess. What is the likely route of spread of 
infection to the mediastinum?

options.a: Between buccopharyngeal fascia and alar fascia.
options.b: Between alar fascia and prevertebral fascia
options.c: Between the capsule of tonsil and superior constrictor muscle

questions.explanation:
The likely route of spread of infection is between the alar fascia anteriorly and the prevertebral 
fascia posteriorly. It is also called the danger space or alar space. It lies just posterior to the retropharyngeal space. It extends from the skull base to the diaphragm. 
Infections from this space can spread to the mediastinum, and hence it is named the danger 
space. 488 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: Given below is an X-ray of a child who presented with stridor. What is your diagnosis? 481 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image is suggestive of a retropharyngeal abscess. It can be diagnosed on a lateral x-ray 
of the soft tissues of the neck. The features include : • Widening of the prevertebral soft tissue shadow • Loss of cervical lordosis • In an acute abscess, air-fluid levels can be seen.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following options is synonymous with quinsy?
questions.explanation:
Quinsy is synonymous with peritonsillar abscess. It is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor 
muscles of the pharynx.

questions.question:
Question 7: A middle-aged diabetic man who had undergone a tooth extraction presents with fever and 
trismus. On examination, his posterior pillar is pushed medially and there is a swelling in the 
neck at the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of parapharyngeal abscess. Parapharyngeal abscess presents with: • Trismus due to spasm of medial pterygoid • Tonsils pushed medially • Swelling in the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid (space limited to the level of hyoid bone). Option A - Retropharyngeal abscess presents as a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall on one 
side of the midline. Option C - In Ludwig’s angina, tonsils are not pushed medially. Option D - Peritonsillar abscess doesn’t produce swelling in the upper 1/3rd of the 
sternocleidomastoid.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is not synonymous with parapharyngeal abscess?
questions.explanation:
Parapharyngeal abscess is not synonymous with medial pharyngeal abscess. Parapharyngeal abscess is synonymous with pharyngomaxillary or lateral pharyngeal or 
pterygomaxillary abscess. 489 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following is correct regarding a parapharyngeal abscess? 482 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Always spreads from the retropharyngeal space
options.c: It has preponderance for male gender

questions.explanation:
Parapharyngeal abscess has a preponderance for male gender. Parapharyngeal abscess is an emergency condition. Infection can spread to the parapharyngeal 
space from any of the other deep neck spaces - peritonsillar, retropharyngeal and submandibular 
spaces. It commonly spreads from a dental infection, tonsillitis or peritonsillar abscesses. The 
patient is usually systemically unwell, with severe trismus and possibly airway compromise. Initial broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics should include cover against streptococci and 
anaerobic organisms. Carotid sheath vessel thrombosis, necrotizing fasciitis and mediastinitis are some of the 
complications. Marked neck swelling, airway compromise, and male gender appear to be predictive of higher-risk 
cases.

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following features will not be manifested in an infection of the post-styloid 
compartment of the parapharyngeal space?
questions.explanation:
Trismus is not a feature of infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space. 
Trismus is seen in pre-styloid abscess due to the involvement of medial pterygoid muscle. Parapharyngeal space is divided into two compartments by the styloid process and its 
attachments. Clinical features depend on the compartment involved. In a post-styloid abscess, there is a bulge of the pharynx behind the posterior pillar, accompanied 
by paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X (resulting in vocal cord paralysis), XI, XII, and the sympathetic 
chain, which can manifest as Horner's syndrome. Swelling in the parotid region may also be 
present. Notably, trismus, the inability to fully open the mouth, is usually absent in this type of 
abscess. A pre-styloid abscess exhibits distinct features including the prolapse of the tonsil and tonsillar 
fossa, along with trismus caused by the spasm of the medial pterygoid muscle. Marked 
odynophagia is common. Additionally, an external swelling can be observed behind the angle of 
the jaw. Fever, sore throat, torticollis (caused by spasm of the prevertebral muscles), and signs of systemic 
toxicity are common features. Diagnosis can be established using a contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT). If there is suspicion of 
thrombosis of the internal jugular vein or an aneurysm of the internal carotid artery, magnetic 
resonance arteriography (MRA) can be useful. Patients require intravenous antibiotic therapy with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, carbapenem 
antibiotics plus drugs that target anaerobic organisms, such as clindamycin or metronidazole. A 
parapharyngeal abscess is drained by an external horizontal incision made on the skin a few 
centimeters below the angle of the mandible. The image attached below shows the components of both spaces: 490 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 11: In which of the following clinical scenarios will you not perform an intraoral incision?

options.a: A 21-year-old woman with fever, hot potato voice and bulging of soft palate and anterior pillar
options.b: A 50-year-old diabetic man with fever, neck swelling over upper ■ rd of the left
options.c: A 3-year-old child with fever and swelling in the posterior pharyngeal wall lateral to the midline
options.d: A 50-year-old man with fever due to penetrating injury of oral mucosa by wood splinters

questions.explanation:
An intraoral incision is not sufficient in the case of option B - parapharyngeal abscess. An external 
neck incision must be made always to ensure complete drainage of the abscess. Option A- This is a case of quinsy as the child has odynophagia and a hot potato voice. Option B - This is a case of parapharyngeal abscess as the swelling is in the upper 1/3rd of the 
neck and the tonsil of the same side is pushed medially Option C- This is a case of retropharyngeal abscess since there is fever and swelling in the 
posterior pharyngeal wall lateral to the midline. Option D- This is a case of Sublingual abscess involving the sublingual space which is caused by 
penetrating injuries of oral mucosa due to fishbone or wood splinters. Indications for Incision and Drainage: • Sublingual abscess: Always intraoral incision • Parapharyngeal abscess: Always external neck incision. • Peritonsillar abscess: Always intraoral. • Retropharyngeal abscess: • Intraoral - in rose position • External - Dean approach • Ludwig’s angina: • Intraoral—if the infection is still localized to sublingual space. • External—if the infection involves submaxillary space. 491 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, 
painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external 
facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely? 483 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario describes a child with fever, otalgia, trismus, and odynophagia with a 
normal external facial examination. The oral cavity shows congested and edematous tonsil and 
tonsillar pillars with edematous uvula pushed to the opposite side. These findings are highly 
suggestive of quinsy (peritonsillar abscess). It is the collection of pus in the peritonsillar space between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and 
the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. Both aerobic and anaerobic organisms are seen. Patient presents with fever, unilateral throat pain, odynophagia, hot potato voice, torticollis, foul 
breath, referred otalgia through glossopharyngeal nerve and trismus due to spasm of pterygoid 
muscles. Oral cavity examination may show congested and edematous tonsils, pillars, and soft palate on the 
involved side. Edematous uvula pushed to the opposite side. Pus may be seen on the tonsillar 
region. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes may be enlarged. The management of quinsy is by antibiotics and incision and drainage to drain the abscess 
followed by interval tonsillectomy 4 to 6 weeks later. Rare complications seen are parapharyngeal abscess, edema of the larynx, septicemia, lung 
abscess, or jugular vein thrombosis. Other options: Option A: Pharyngitis presents with fever, throat pain, enlarged tonsils, and lymphoid follicles on 
the posterior pharyngeal wall. Option B: Parotid abscess occurs due to the suppuration of parotid space. It presents with 
swelling, redness, firmness, and tenderness in the parotid area and at the angle of the mandible. It 
is usually unilateral, but bilateral abscesses can occur. Due to the thick capsule, fluctuation is 
often difficult to elicit. Option C: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection/pus breaks 
through the thin medial side of the tip of the mastoid and presents as a swelling in the upper part 
of the neck.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following statements about quinsy is false?

options.a: Collection of pus between the capsule of tonsil and superior constrictor
options.b: Presents with odynophagia and drooling of saliva

questions.explanation:
Peritonsillar abscess or quinsy is usually unilateral. It is a collection of pus in the peritonsillar space which lies between the capsule of the tonsil and 
the superior constrictor muscle. Usually, it is unilateral though occasionally bilateral abscesses are recorded. It presents with marked odynophagia such that the patient cannot even swallow his saliva which 
dribbles from the angle of his mouth. The patient is usually dehydrated. Muffled and thick speech, often called hot potato voice. 492 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A 16-year-old girl presented with complaints of fever, right-sided throat pain, and difficulty in 
swallowing. On examination, she had hot potato speech and halitosis. The right tonsil was not 
visualised due to oedematous pillars and the uvula was pushed to the left. How will you 
manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of peritonsillar abscess or quinsy and management 
involves incision and drainage with antibiotics. Management of quinsy • Hospitalization • Intravenous fluids to combat dehydration • Antibiotics - Suitable antibiotics in large IV doses to cover aerobes and anaerobes • Analgesics • Drainage by needle aspiration or incision and drainage • Tonsillectomy when there is airway obstruction or recurrence. Incision and drainage of the abscess: A peritonsillar abscess is opened at the point of the 
maximum bulge above the upper pole of the tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of the 
anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula.

questions.question:
Question 15: In a patient with recurrent peritonsillar abscess, when is the ideal time to perform a 
tonsillectomy?
questions.explanation:
In a patient with recurrent peritonsillar abscess (quinsy), ideally, an interval tonsillectomy is done 
4-6 weeks after the infection settles down. Hot tonsillectomy: Earlier tonsillectomy was done during incision and drainage. But this is not 
followed now as it is dangerous and can lead to aspiration, bleeding & spread of infection.

questions.question:
Question 16: A patient presents with complaints of pain while swallowing since 2 days. He also gives a 
history of toothache since 1 week. On examination, there is a swelling and erythema as in the 
figure below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Ludwig’s angina. Ludwig’s angina is an infection of the submandibular space which lies between the mucous 
membrane of the floor of the mouth and tongue on one side and the superficial layer of deep 
cervical fascia extending between the hyoid bone and mandible on the other.

questions.question:
Question 17: 485 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is a false statement about Ludwig’s angina?

options.a: It involves both sublingual and submandibular space
options.c: Dental infections are the most common cause
options.d: H.influenza is the most common organism implicated.

questions.explanation:
Mixed infection with aerobes and anaerobes is seen in Ludwig’s angina. Among these 
alpha-hemolytic streptococci, staphylococci and Bacteroides groups are common. Ludwig’s angina is an infection of the submandibular space. The space is divided into two compartments by the mylohyoid muscle: • Sublingual compartment (above the mylohyoid). • Submandibular and submental compartment (below the mylohyoid). 493 
Sold by @itachibot The two compartments are continuous around the posterior border of the mylohyoid muscle. Both 
compartments freely communicate in the midline with the opposite side. Therefore infection 
rapidly becomes bilateral. The most common cause of Ludwig's angina is dental infections (accounts for 80%) of cases.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 23-year-old man presents to the OPD with odynophagia and swelling. He is diagnosed with 
Ludwig’s angina. How might you describe the swelling?

options.a: Tender fluctuant swelling in the floor of mouth
options.b: Tender fluctuant swelling in the parotid region
options.c: Woody hard swelling in the floor of mouth
options.d: Woody hard swelling in the parotid region

questions.explanation:
Ludwig's angina presents as a tender woody hard swelling on the floor of the mouth. There can be marked difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) with varying degrees of trismus. The 
tongue is progressively pushed upwards and backward, threatening the airway. Laryngeal edema 
may also be present. Usually, there is cellulitis of the tissues rather than frank abscess. Incision and drainage show 
salted pork appearance.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 50-year-old man with multiple comorbidities, post-op day 5 of major abdominal surgery 
has developed high-grade fever and swelling over the parotid area. On examination, there is 
tenderness, induration and pus exuding from the Stenson’s duct on applying pressure over 
the parotids. Which of the following options is not a likely cause for the above condition?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of a parotid abscess and excessive gland stimulation is 
not a cause for its formation. Etiology of Parotid Abscess: • Dehydration, particularly in postsurgical cases (5-7 post-op days) and debilitated patients, with 
stasis of salivary flow is the predisposing cause. • Infection from the oral cavity travels via the Stenson’s duct to invade the parotid gland 
(retrograde spread of infection). The most common organism is Staphylococcus aureus but 
Streptococci, anaerobic organisms, and rarely the gram negative organisms have also been 
cultured.

questions.question:
Question 20: A patient with a parotid abscess is planned for incision and drainage (I & D). Which of 
the following practices will you avoid in this patient?
questions.explanation:
In a case of a parotid abscess, one must never wait for fluctuation or pus point to occur. This is 
because the superficial layer of parotidomasseteric fascia is tense and the fluctuation will be 
apparent only in later stages. A parotid abscess refers to an infection and pus formation in the parotid space. It is caused most 
commonly by Staphylococcus aureus. Post-surgical cases and debilitated patients with stasis of 
salivary flow are at risk of developing parotid abscesses. Patients typically present with unilateral swelling, redness, induration, and tenderness over the 
parotid gland and angle of the mandible. Dehydration and fever are also present. Diagnosis is by 
ultrasonography or a CT scan. Multiple small loculi of pus are seen in the parenchyma. Aspiration 
of abscess can be done to determine the culture and sensitivity of the infective agent. 494 
Sold by @itachibot Correction of dehydration, improving oral hygiene and promoting salivary flow. Intravenous 
antibiotics are also used in treatment. Surgical drainage under local or general anesthesia is carried out by a preauricular incision as 
employed for parotidectomy. A skin flap is raised to expose the surface of the gland, and the 
abscess or abscesses are bluntly opened working parallel to the branches of the VIIth nerve. The 
skin incision is loosely approximated over a drain and allowed to heal by secondary intention. 495 
Sold by @itachibot Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma
